channel.title: Let's get down to business

item.title: Let's get down to business
item.dc:creator: @Kryptizzler Kryptizzler
item.description:
@Kryptizzler wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:30, topic:35425”][quote author=White Castle link=topic=50761.msg647632#msg647632 date=1166516897]

It would be possible to load a bot directly from the jagex website in java with BCEL and the -javaagent option for say. I would encourage bot makers to try this alternative. However, personally, I find BCEL much lower level than JVMTI. JVMTI gives you the interface, in BCEL you must create it by toying directly with the bytecodes. Plus I’m a C guy

I’m not worried about my hooks, because the method the bot uses to get client data isn’t through hooks but through jvmti events. I only need one hook and I decided to put it on the main game loop (on entry and exit) so my native function can be called. Other hooks can easily be added in, but I don’t see why I would need them.

If anyone is interested I found a neat article on -javaagent and the bytecode instrumentation library included in jdk 1.5 http://www.javalobby.org/java/forums/t19309.html

Wow, that’s pretty cool. Here’s something I whipped up using BCEL upon class definition via ClassFileTransformer.transform()…:

http://uppit.com/GXZXZ[br][size=1]Posted at: December 18, 2006, 07:27:22 PM[/size][hr]However I did try to make it work with only registering the ClassFileTransformer and then loading Runescape via a web browser, and it didn’t work.
[/quote]

sweet[/quote]I’ve been meaning to do some work with that but I’ve been lazy. Instrumentation is an easier (more limiting) alternative for people who don’t know C/C++ IMO.

Read full topic

item.title: Let's get down to business
item.dc:creator: @wL1 wL
item.description:
@wL1 wrote:

semaphore:

All that aside, it’s nice to see a fellow c[++] developer. I was beginning to wonder if anyone would ever join this scene with more knowledge of c/c++ than how to spell it.

Raises Hand
Even though I can read and code (more or less) in half a dozen of languages, I’d still consider myself a pure C guy. It seems to me that we keep falling back to what we grew up with

Back OT:
I downloaded the archive and feel tempted to look through it and there’s some ideas I had in mind since long ago and I’d definitively like to try some of them. Unfortunately I can’t afford having too many hobbies, so I’m forced to set priorities.
I don’t know whether or when I ever will be back into this.

Anyway, my interest in bots completely vanished in favour of my new toy, a Sharp Zaurus (a sexy mini PC) which has full linux support, even though the existing distributions require some coding to suit all my special needs
I landed here just because I wondered what’s going on bot-wise, so I thought I’ll check this forum again and after enjoying reading some posts of this guy called semaphore I did a search for all his posts. Searches for a few selected people probably directs you to all the interesting topics

Read full topic

item.title: Let's get down to business
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:22, topic:35425”]It’s about bloody time someone with a positive IQ has joined this forum.

It’s a fun idea byte. Although a jvmti solution is insanely impressive from a ‘kung-fu’ standpoint, (Meaning it will gain you loads of respect) from what I’ve seen it is still very difficult to obtain context while ‘tooling’ the bytecode from within the jvm. You (in general not you specfically) must find a way to apply some form of context to the plethora of hooks you are likely to encounter.

All that aside, it’s nice to see a fellow c[++] developer. I was beginning to wonder if anyone would ever join this scene with more knowledge of c/c++ than how to spell it.[/quote]

Go read your dictionary?

Read full topic

JVMTI gives you the interface, in BCEL you must create it by toying directly with the bytecodes. Plus I’m a C guy

I’m not worried about my hooks, because the method the bot uses to get client data isn’t through hooks but through jvmti events. I only need one hook and I decided to put it on the main game loop (on entry and exit) so my native function can be called. Other hooks can easily be added in, but I don’t see why I would need them.

item.title: Let's get down to business
item.dc:creator: @byte byte
item.description:
@byte wrote:

Ah I see where you’re coming from this time.

In our case we encounter 2 types of hooks:

  1. Hook injected by java_crw_demo at the main game loop (yes, I meant the real main game loop).
  2. Hook created by JVMTI when a field is modified.

For #2, the events are only fired on fields of interest. What happens is when the rs class files are loaded I call a function which set watches on only several fields. This means that my field modification callback function is only called when those fields of interest are modified and not all fields of all rs classes. The callback function gives us tons of arguments to determine exactly which field of interest was modified then it updates its value in the agent.

You have to have a means of figuring out which fields or method calls are of importance to you.

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/guide/jvmti/jvmti.html#SetFieldModificationWatch. That’s the function I use to set fields of importance.

Using SetFieldModificationWatch means I need an updater to get wanted field names + signatures (should stay constant anyways) every update so I can get their new jfieldID. An updater shouldn’t be too hard, it could probably even be done in an awk script.

Read full topic

item.title: Let's get down to business
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

[quote=“byte, post:24, topic:35425”]It would be possible to load a bot directly from the jagex website in java with BCEL and the -javaagent option for say. I would encourage bot makers to try this alternative. However, personally, I find BCEL much lower level than JVMTI. JVMTI gives you the interface, in BCEL you must create it by toying directly with the bytecodes. Plus I’m a C guy

I’m not worried about my hooks, because the method the bot uses to get client data isn’t through hooks but through jvmti events. I only need one hook and I decided to put it on the main game loop (on entry and exit) so my native function can be called. Other hooks can easily be added in, but I don’t see why I would need them.[/quote]

A simple misunderstanding. I am using the term hook in a more abstract way.

I agree with you that a jvmti approach is much cleaner and easier to implement. Also, because it is c-based it pretty much draws a line in the sand and just about everyone in the community will be left scratching their heads. However, I think you misunderstand the complexity involved with finding sense out of every event that you are going to encounter. As a case and point, how do you plan to figure out what classes you intend to hook for callbacks for class load or for field access/mutation events? You have to have a means of figuring out which fields or method calls are of importance to you. Otherwise you will be inundated with thousands of events (assuming you hook all of them) and no method of sifting the wheat from the chaff. One of the first issues I ran into when first trying what you’re doing is finding context. Sure it is fantastic to be notified of every single modification/access of every single field… but where do I draw the correlation to what change means what. This is the part that makes things a bit hairy.

Sure it’s incredibly easy to obtain a hook to get client data using jvmti events. The problem is once you have that hook in your hands you’ll be left with the ‘wtf face’ look thinking ‘ok… now what?’. Even if you hook on the main game loop (I’m assuming you mean the real main game loop code location and not some abstract ‘main game loop’), you are still left wondering 'ok now which of the 150 of these fields on this client is the field I’m looking for.

There is a solution to this problem. I just wanted to get that out there so that the kiddies have something to think about before they step out onto the field and play with the big boys.

Read full topic

item.title: Let's get down to business
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:22, topic:35425”]It’s about bloody time someone with a positive IQ has joined this forum.

It’s a fun idea byte. Although a jvmti solution is insanely impressive from a ‘kung-fu’ standpoint, (Meaning it will gain you loads of respect) from what I’ve seen it is still very difficult to obtain context while ‘tooling’ the bytecode from within the jvm. You (in general not you specfically) must find a way to apply some form of context to the plethora of hooks you are likely to encounter.

All that aside, it’s nice to see a fellow c[++] developer. I was beginning to wonder if anyone would ever join this scene with more knowledge of c/c++ than how to spell it.[/quote]
I know more than how to spell c/c++, I know what int main(); is =O

Read full topic

item.title: Let's get down to business
item.dc:creator: @byte byte
item.description:
@byte wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:22, topic:35425”]It’s about bloody time someone with a positive IQ has joined this forum.

It’s a fun idea byte. Although a jvmti solution is insanely impressive from a ‘kung-fu’ standpoint, (Meaning it will gain you loads of respect) from what I’ve seen it is still very difficult to obtain context while ‘tooling’ the bytecode from within the jvm. You (in general not you specfically) must find a way to apply some form of context to the plethora of hooks you are likely to encounter.

All that aside, it’s nice to see a fellow c[++] developer. I was beginning to wonder if anyone would ever join this scene with more knowledge of c/c++ than how to spell it.[/quote]

All legitimate runescapers will load the game from the official website. What I wanted when I started looking at my possibilities was a bot that would be able to do just that. All you need in this case is to change the applet runtime parameters to load the jvmti agent and you’re botting off their website. I haven’t had enough time to look into the client to find traps yet but I would imagine this nullifies several of them. As long as Jagex doesn’t start watching the client jvm I have nothing to worry about.

It would be possible to load a bot directly from the jagex website in java with BCEL and the -javaagent option for say. I would encourage bot makers to try this alternative. However, personally, I find BCEL much lower level than JVMTI. JVMTI gives you the interface, in BCEL you must create it by toying directly with the bytecodes. Plus I’m a C guy

I’m not worried about my hooks, because the method the bot uses to get client data isn’t through hooks but through jvmti events. I only need one hook and I decided to put it on the main game loop (on entry and exit) so my native function can be called. Other hooks can easily be added in, but I don’t see why I would need them.

If anyone is interested I found a neat article on -javaagent and the bytecode instrumentation library included in jdk 1.5 http://www.javalobby.org/java/forums/t19309.html

Read full topic

item.title: Let's get down to business
item.dc:creator: @byte byte
item.description:
@byte wrote:

Put something like this in a shell script:

gcc -c -Ipath_to_jvmti_and java_crw_demo_includes -o ../bin/rumacs.o rumacs.c
ar rcs ../bin/rumacs.a ../bin/rumacs.o

It also seems gcc is complaining about the exit function, try adding a 0 as parameter.

Read full topic

item.title: Let's get down to business
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

rictoo@rictoo-desktop:~/TEMP/rumacs/lib/src$ gcc ../bin rumacs.c In file included from rumacs.h:8, from rumacs.c:7: java_crw_demo.h:40:17: error: jni.h: No such file or directory In file included from rumacs.c:7: rumacs.h:48:7: warning: no newline at end of file rumacs.c: In function ‘hook_entry_native’: rumacs.c:80: warning: passing argument 5 of ‘(*jvmti)->GetStackTrace’ from incompatible pointer type rumacs.c: In function ‘cb_vmstart’: rumacs.c:126: warning: incompatible implicit declaration of built-in function ‘exit’ rumacs.c:126: error: too few arguments to function ‘exit’ rumacs.c:129: warning: passing argument 3 of ‘(*jni)->RegisterNatives’ from incompatible pointer type rumacs.c:133: warning: incompatible implicit declaration of built-in function ‘exit’ rumacs.c:133: error: too few arguments to function ‘exit’ rumacs.c: In function ‘cb_classfileloadhook’: rumacs.c:173: warning: assignment makes pointer from integer without a cast rumacs.c:179: warning: incompatible implicit declaration of built-in function ‘exit’ rumacs.c:179: error: too few arguments to function ‘exit’ rumacs.c: In function ‘check_error’: rumacs.c:243: warning: incompatible implicit declaration of built-in function ‘exit’ rumacs.c:243: error: too few arguments to function ‘exit’ rumacs.c:245:2: warning: no newline at end of file rictoo@rictoo-desktop:~/TEMP/rumacs/lib/src$

=/

EDIT: I tried compiling with g++ and I get the exact same errors =’(
